entry.et: Middle English, from Medieval Latin minerale, from neuter of mineralis

def.dt: :ore
:an inorganic substance (as in the ash of calcined tissue)
:mine
:something neither animal nor vegetable
:a solid homogeneous crystalline chemical element or compound that results from the inorganic processes of nature
:any of various naturally occurring homogeneous substances (as stone, coal, salt, sulfur, sand, petroleum, water, or natural gas) obtained usually from the ground
:a synthetic substance having the chemical composition and crystalline form and properties of a naturally occurring mineral
:mineral water

entry.et: Middle English, from Medieval Latin mineralis, from minera mine, ore, from Old French minere, miniere, from mine

def.dt: :of or relating to minerals
:inorganic
:impregnated with mineral substances
:a basic group of natural objects that includes inorganic objects compare animal kingdom plant kingdom
:an oil of mineral origin
:a refined petroleum oil used especially as a laxative

entry.fl: noun plural but singular or plural in construction

def.dt: :a petroleum distillate that is used especially as a paint or varnish thinner
:water naturally or artificially infused with mineral salts or gases (as carbon dioxide)
:a wax of mineral origin
:ozokerite
:any of various lightweight vitreous fibrous materials used especially in heat and sound insulation
:any of a group of hydrous silicates of aluminum and sometimes other metals formed chiefly in weathering processes and occurring especially in clay and shale
:the dried bodies of the females of various scale insects (genus Kermes) that are found on a Mediterranean oak (Quercus coccifera) and constitute a red dyestuff
:the dye
